unnormalised: ## Going Viral, Indian Style: Decoding Today's Social Media Trends
normalised: ## Going Viral, Indian Style: Decoding Today's Social Media Trends

unnormalised: Hey everyone! Ever wonder what makes a video of a street vendor in Chandni Chowk suddenly explode or a meme about auntyji's chai so relatable that it floods your WhatsApp groups? That, my friends, is the magic (and madness!) of virality in the age of social media.

unnormalised: In the ever-evolving landscape of influencer marketing, understanding virality trends is crucial. What worked on 26/01/2023, Republic Day, might be ancient history by Diwali. Things move FAST. Today, it's all about authenticity and relatable content. People are tired of overly-produced, picture-perfect posts. They crave genuine stories, real struggles, and hilarious observations about daily life.

unnormalised: Think about it: remember that reel of Priya trying to parallel park her Scooty in Karol Bagh? Pure gold! Why? Because every other Delhiite has been there! That's the power of connecting with your audience on a personal level.

unnormalised: So, what's trending now? Short-form video content, for sure. Reels, TikToks, YouTube Shorts – they're all the rage. But it's not just about jumping on the bandwagon. The key is to put your own spin on things, give it that Desi tadka. Think about using trending sounds but adding a Bollywood twist, or participating in a viral dance challenge but incorporating some Bharatnatyam steps.

unnormalised: Don't forget the power of memes! A well-placed meme referencing something culturally relevant – like the pressure of cracking the IIT-JEE exam (results usually out around 09:00 hrs on results day!) – can spread like wildfire. Collaboration is also key! Partnering with other influencers or brands can amplify your reach and get your content in front of new audiences.

unnormalised: But beware! What's considered viral on 15/08/1947, Independence Day, probably won't fly now. Keep a close eye on current events, stay informed about trending topics, and most importantly, be respectful. A poorly thought-out campaign can backfire spectacularly.
